description: Sino-Vietnamese Disambiguation RAG v2.0 — Unified database merging 4 sources + corpus analysis

changelog.v2.0: Merged RAG v1 (722) + kanji_difficult (71+78) + context_rules (25) + false_cognates (2) + corpus scanner (27). Fixed false cognate indexing bug. Added register substitutions. Added negative vectors.

notes.purpose: Context-aware disambiguation of Hán-Việt homonyms for JP→VN translation
key_improvements_v2: false_cognates now inside pattern_categories (was stranded, never indexed)
register_substitutions: 3-tier Hán Việt vs native Vietnamese by genre
corpus_discovered: 27 high-frequency compounds missing from all prior sources
negative_vectors: per-category negative anchors for precision
unified schema: all patterns use contexts[] format for consistent indexing

sino_disambiguation.description: Context-aware Hán-Việt homonym resolution for polysemous characters

examples.note: In cultivation context, not 'luck'
In casual context, means 'luck'
Proper noun - cultivation realm
In cultivation: joining a sect

patterns.explanation: Foundation Establishment realm - proper noun, use Sino-Vietnamese
Golden Core realm - proper noun, use Sino-Vietnamese
Nascent Soul realm - proper noun, use Sino-Vietnamese

cultivation_techniques.description: Cultivation technique and skill naming conventions

japanese_light_novel.description: High-frequency Japanese light novel kanji compounds with Sino-Vietnamese disambiguation

false_cognates.description: False cognates: same kanji, completely different meanings by context. CRITICAL for disambiguation.

examples.note: In cultivation context (修炼, 丹田) → vận khí. In casual context (好运, 幸运) → may mắn
In cultivation context (修炼, 丹田) → vận khí. In casual context (好运, 幸运) → may mắn
In cultivation context (入魔, 修炼) → tẩu hỏa. With weapons → bắn nhầm
In cultivation context (入魔, 修炼) → tẩu hỏa. With weapons → bắn nhầm

register_substitutions.description: Register-aware substitutions: Hán Việt vs native Vietnamese by genre/context tier

examples.note: Modern apartment entrance - 'huyền quan' is literary/archaic, 'cửa chính' is contemporary
In formal/historical context, huyền quan is appropriate
Modern teen context - 'thiếu nữ' sounds like historical novel, 'cô gái' is natural
In formal/historical context, thiếu nữ is appropriate
Modern casual - 'mỹ thiếu nữ' is literary, 'cô gái xinh đẹp' is contemporary teen speech
In formal/historical context, mỹ thiếu nữ is appropriate
Daily meal - 'thực sự' is formal/written, 'bữa ăn' is spoken
In formal/historical context, thực sự is appropriate
Modern school - 'học hiệu' is archaic, 'trường học' is standard
In formal/historical context, học hiệu is appropriate
Kitchen - 'đài sở' is archaic literary, 'bếp' is natural
In formal/historical context, đài sở is appropriate
Room - 'bộ ốc' is literary, 'phòng' is contemporary
In formal/historical context, bộ ốc is appropriate
Friend - 'hữu nhân' is classical, 'bạn' is casual contemporary
In formal/historical context, hữu nhân is appropriate
Mother - 'mẫu thân' is formal/filial, 'mẹ' is natural family address
In formal/historical context, mẫu thân is appropriate
Father - 'phụ thân' is formal/filial, 'bố/ba' is natural family address
In formal/historical context, phụ thân is appropriate
Older brother - 'huynh' is classical, 'anh' is contemporary
In formal/historical context, huynh is appropriate
Older sister - 'tỷ' is classical, 'chị' is contemporary
In formal/historical context, tỷ is appropriate
Younger brother - 'đệ' is classical, 'em trai' is contemporary
In formal/historical context, đệ is appropriate
Younger sister - 'muội' is classical, 'em gái' is contemporary
In formal/historical context, muội is appropriate
Girlfriend/she - 'bỉ nữ' is archaic, 'cô ấy' (she) or 'bạn gái' (girlfriend) is natural
In formal/historical context, bỉ nữ is appropriate
Boyfriend/he - 'anh ấy' (he) or 'bạn trai' (boyfriend) is natural
In formal/historical context, bỉ thị is appropriate
Technical political terminology - Sino-Vietnamese is standard
Economic terminology - Sino-Vietnamese is standard
Scientific terminology - Sino-Vietnamese is standard
Educational terminology - Sino-Vietnamese is standard
Legal terminology - Sino-Vietnamese is standard
Medical diagnosis - Sino-Vietnamese is standard terminology
Royal palace - Sino-Vietnamese maintains formality for period setting
In modern/casual context, lâu đài is more natural
Keep 'samurai' for recognition or 'võ sĩ' for Vietnamese adaptation
In modern/casual context, samurai is more natural
In formal contexts, 'thanh niên' is appropriate
In modern/casual context, chàng trai is more natural

kanji_difficult_compounds.description: Difficult kanji with production-validated translations. Includes rare/archaic characters and their compounds.

examples.note: Often appears in 綺麗{きれい}. High RTAS context (4.5+) requires careful tone. Furigana indicates single-word reading.
Han-Viet 'lệ' too formal for romcom. Use 'xinh đẹp', 'rạng rỡ' depending on context. Distinguish compound vs standalone usage.
Han-Viet 'lệ' too formal for romcom. Use 'xinh đẹp', 'rạng rỡ' depending on context. Distinguish compound vs standalone usage.
瞳 (hitomi) vs 目 (me) - 瞳 more poetic/emotional, emphasizes pupil/inner eye. Han-Viet 'đồng tử' too clinical. Use 'đôi mắt', 'ánh mắt' for RTAS 4.0+ scenes.
眼差し (manazashi) vs 視線 (shisen) - manazashi more poetic, emphasizes emotion. Han-Viet 'nhãn' too formal. Often modified: 真剣な眼差し (serious gaze).
眼差し (manazashi) vs 視線 (shisen) - manazashi more poetic, emphasizes emotion. Han-Viet 'nhãn' too formal. Often modified: 真剣な眼差し (serious gaze).
眼差し (manazashi) vs 視線 (shisen) - manazashi more poetic, emphasizes emotion. Han-Viet 'nhãn' too formal. Often modified: 真剣な眼差し (serious gaze).
許嫁 (iinazuke) is plot keyword for arranged marriage trope. Distinguish from 婚約者 (fiancé via mutual engagement). Core term for romcom subgenre.
許嫁 (iinazuke) is plot keyword for arranged marriage trope. Distinguish from 婚約者 (fiancé via mutual engagement). Core term for romcom subgenre.
清楚 (seiso) is character archetype keyword. Often contrasted with 色気 (sexiness). Use 'thanh tao', 'trong sáng', 'tinh khôi' for variety.
清楚 (seiso) is character archetype keyword. Often contrasted with 色気 (sexiness). Use 'thanh tao', 'trong sáng', 'tinh khôi' for variety.
蠱惑 (kowaku) is literary term. Han-Viet 'cổ hoặc' archaic. Use 'quyến rũ', 'mê hoặc' for RTAS 4.5+ scenes. Must convey allure without vulgarity.
蠱惑 (kowaku) is literary term. Han-Viet 'cổ hoặc' archaic. Use 'quyến rũ', 'mê hoặc' for RTAS 4.5+ scenes. Must convey allure without vulgarity.
蹲る (uzukumaru) conveys vulnerability. Han-Viet 'tồn' rare. Use 'co ro', 'thu mình' to preserve emotional tone. Common in bullying/trauma flashbacks.
蹲る (uzukumaru) conveys vulnerability. Han-Viet 'tồn' rare. Use 'co ro', 'thu mình' to preserve emotional tone. Common in bullying/trauma flashbacks.
諫める (isameru) vs 戒める (imashimeru) - 諫 = respectful remonstration, 戒 = strict warning. Distinguish tone. Use 'khuyên bảo', 'nhắc nhở' for playful context.
諫める (isameru) vs 戒める (imashimeru) - 諫 = respectful remonstration, 戒 = strict warning. Distinguish tone. Use 'khuyên bảo', 'nhắc nhở' for playful context.
お揃い (osoroi) implies pride in matching with loved one. Han-Viet 'toàn' not intuitive. Use 'giống nhau', 'cùng màu' with emotional undertone.
お揃い (osoroi) implies pride in matching with loved one. Han-Viet 'toàn' not intuitive. Use 'giống nhau', 'cùng màu' with emotional undertone.
Common in character names (female). 凛々しい for male dignity, 凛とした for female composure. Han-Viet 'lẫm' rare.
Common in character names (female). 凛々しい for male dignity, 凛とした for female composure. Han-Viet 'lẫm' rare.
Common in character names (female). 凛々しい for male dignity, 凛とした for female composure. Han-Viet 'lẫm' rare.
Highly poetic. Use 'phù du', 'thoáng qua', 'mỏng manh' for wistful tone. Common in tragic romance or philosophical reflection.
Highly poetic. Use 'phù du', 'thoáng qua', 'mỏng manh' for wistful tone. Common in tragic romance or philosophical reflection.
Common in school LN. 憧れる (akogareru) = yearn for, admire. Use 'khát khao', 'ngưỡng mộ' for romantic admiration context.
Common in school LN. 憧れる (akogareru) = yearn for, admire. Use 'khát khao', 'ngưỡng mộ' for romantic admiration context.
頬 (hoo) for cheek. Han-Viet 'giáp' not common. Use 'má' (Vietnamese). Common in RTAS 4.0+ intimate scenes.
頬 (hoo) for cheek. Han-Viet 'giáp' not common. Use 'má' (Vietnamese). Common in RTAS 4.0+ intimate scenes.
Archaic first-person pronoun (feminine). Common in historical/fantasy LN with feudal settings. Han-Viet 'thiếp' directly maps.
Archaic first-person pronoun (feminine). Common in historical/fantasy LN with feudal settings. Han-Viet 'thiếp' directly maps.
Archaic first-person pronoun (feminine). Common in historical/fantasy LN with feudal settings. Han-Viet 'thiếp' directly maps.
Core term for historical/fantasy LN. Often romanized 'samurai' in Vietnamese. Han-Viet 'thị' less common than loan word.
刀 (katana) vs 剣 (tsurugi) - 刀 = curved blade (katana), 剣 = straight blade. Distinguish in martial contexts. Han-Viet 'đao' maps well.
刀 (katana) vs 剣 (tsurugi) - 刀 = curved blade (katana), 剣 = straight blade. Distinguish in martial contexts. Han-Viet 'đao' maps well.
刀 (katana) vs 剣 (tsurugi) - 刀 = curved blade (katana), 剣 = straight blade. Distinguish in martial contexts. Han-Viet 'đao' maps well.
剣 (tsurugi/ken) = straight blade. Differentiate from 刀 (curved katana). Common in fantasy RPG settings. Han-Viet 'kiếm' perfect match.
剣 (tsurugi/ken) = straight blade. Differentiate from 刀 (curved katana). Common in fantasy RPG settings. Han-Viet 'kiếm' perfect match.
Ultra-rare. Archery equipment in historical battles. No Han-Viet mapping. Translate as 'ống đựng tên', 'hộp tên'.
Common in historical/fantasy female character descriptions. Han-Viet 'trâm' maps well. Often ornamental, symbolic of status.
Ultra-rare. Horse equipment in feudal contexts. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively as 'dây trâm ngực ngựa'.
Rare. Horse tack in historical military contexts. No Han-Viet. Use 'dây cương', 'hàm thiếc'.
Ultra-rare. Mounted archery equipment. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Rare archery equipment. No Han-Viet. Use 'nhẫn bắn cung', 'bọc ngón tay'.
Chinese mythical creature. Rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Romanize 'xiezhi' or translate descriptively.
Rare mythical creature. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively as 'khỉ khổng lồ thần thoại'.
Chinese folklore creature. Use 'yêu tinh núi', 'ma quỷ núi'. No Han-Viet.
Rare marine creature. No Han-Viet. Use 'cua móng ngựa'.
Archaic kanji for crocodile (modern: 鰐). Use 'cá sấu'. No Han-Viet.
Famous Japanese yokai. Romanize 'nue' or translate as 'quái vật Nhật Bản'. No Han-Viet.
Rare variant for phoenix. Use 'phượng hoàng'. No Han-Viet.
Chinese mythical bird symbolizing conjugal love. Use 'chim uyên ương thần thoại'. No Han-Viet.
Medical/anatomical term. Rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Use 'xương đùi', 'ổ khớp hông'.
Anatomical term. Rare in LN except medical/injury scenes. No Han-Viet. Use 'xương bả vai'.
Medical term. Very rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Use 'xương bánh chè'.
Archaic for skull (modern: 頭蓋骨). Rare in LN except horror/dark fantasy. No Han-Viet. Use 'hộp sọ'.
Archaic punishment term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Translate as 'hình phạt cạo đầu'.
Archaic negative descriptor. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'đần độn', 'ngây thơ'.
Archaic descriptor for barbaric characters. No Han-Viet. Use 'hung dữ', 'man rợ'.
Archaic term for beauty/adornment. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'trang điểm đẹp', 'nhan sắc'.
Archaic clothing. Rare except historical/xianxia fantasy. No Han-Viet. Use 'áo choàng lông'.
Very rare. Archaic footwear term. No Han-Viet. Use 'dép', 'giày trẻ em'.
Ultra-rare archaic clothing. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Archaic term for wig. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'tóc giả'.
Archaic hairstyle term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'tóc xõa'.
Mourning ritual hairstyle. Ultra-rare. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Archaic hairstyle verb. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'búi tóc', 'cột tóc'.
Animal feature. Common in fantasy with horses/lions. No Han-Viet. Use 'bờm'.
Literary euphemism for death. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'qua đời', 'băng hà'.
Tragic death term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'chết đói'.
Archaic hunting method. Rare. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Seasonal hunting term. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Archaic verb for washing face. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'rửa mặt'.
Poetic verb for soaring. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'bay vút', 'bay cao'.
Archaic food term. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'cá khô'.
Variant for dried fish. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'cá khô'.
Dried seafood. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'mực khô'.
Archaic cooking vessel. Rare except fantasy kitchens. No Han-Viet. Use 'nồi gang', 'vạc lớn'.
Culinary term. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'trứng cá'.
Literary bird metaphor for colleagues. Ultra-rare. No Han-Viet. Translate metaphorically.
Rare bird species. Ultra-rare in LN. No Han-Viet. Translate descriptively.
Poetic variant for swallow (modern: 燕). Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'chim yến'.
Rare bird, also symbol of 5th grade official. Historical contexts. No Han-Viet.
Archaic for chick (modern: 雛). Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'gà con', 'chim non'.
Variant for quiver. Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'túi đựng tên', 'bao tên'.
Horse equipment. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'tấm lót yên ngựa'.
Archaic for reins (modern: 手綱). Rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'dây cương'.
Archaic musical instrument. Very rare. No Han-Viet. Use 'trống cầm tay'.
Traditional Japanese/Chinese instrument. Rare. No Han-Viet. Romanize 'sho' or use 'sáo sheng'.
Archaic variant of 闘 (fight). Rare. Han-Viet 'đấu' maps. Use 'chiến đấu', 'đấu tranh'.
Another archaic variant of 闘. Very rare. Han-Viet 'đấu' maps. Use 'thi đấu', 'tranh đấu'.
